There may be pockets of areas in Mexico where there have been some gains for the local population. But, as a whole, Mexicans have become poorer from NAFTA.

NAFTA at 20: Lori Wallach on U.S. Job Losses, Record Income Inequality, Mass Displacement in Mexico
http://www.democracynow.org/2014/1/3/nafta_at_20_lori_wallach_on

“The North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Mexico and Canada went into effect 20 years ago this week on January 1, 1994. Hundreds of thousands of U.S. jobs have vanished as companies sought lower-wage workers in Mexico. Meanwhile, NAFTA has generated more poverty in Mexico, forcing millions of citizens to migrate to the United States in search of work.

“One group that saw much of this coming was the indigenous people in the Mexican state of Chiapas. On the same day NAFTA went into effect, on January 1st, 1994, they joined the Zapatista National Liberation Army, or EZLN, in declaring war on the Mexican government, saying that NAFTA meant death to indigenous peoples. They took over five major towns in Chiapas, with fully armed women and men. The uprising was a shock, even for those who for years worked in the very communities where the rebel army had been secretly organizing.”

Local,

Our trade agreements were designed to benefit corporate America, Wall Street, and their top executives. Americans should not be asked to compete with workers who earn 20-30 cents an hour and with countries that lack adequate environmental and safety standards. Our goal is to bring them up, not us down.

As a result of NAFTA, CAFTA, and Permanent Normal Trade Relations with China not only have we lost tens of thousands of factories and millions of jobs, American workers are now more competitive with low-wage countries.

Actually, Mexico has a growing middle class and the issue has always been that they are happy to outsource their social services to the US, while politicians of both parties want to keep wages low, so as to appease their corporate masters.

The biggest issue with Mexico has always been that the richest country in the world cannot have a Third World country on their border. The more Mexicans who are in the middle class, the better for the US as a whole, as they too will need low-skilled workers and with a low supply, the wages will rise and workers will not emigrate.

Twenty years after the passage of NAFTA, it has failed to deliver on the promises made by Bill Clinton, corporate America, and others. Clinton claimed the trade deal would create 200,000 jobs by 1995, raise wages, and improve environmental standards. However, nearly one million US jobs have been lost and poverty has increased in Mexico, causing millions of Mexicans to migrate to the US.

The administration is pushing to fast track the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement. Only 5 of the 29 chapters deal with trade. If Congress passes fast track, it will give away its authority to offer amendments and debate will be limited.

More than 600 corporations have had a seat at the table during the negotiations, while Congress and the public have been kept in the dark. Multinationals will be able to sue a government in a foreign tribunal if domestic laws reduce future profits, and lawyers will rotate acting as judges and representing the corporations.

If the TPP is approved it will allow corporations to offshore millions of jobs and ban Buy America policies. The TPP will erode protections in domestic laws and give new powers to multinationals when it comes to labor issues, environmental and safety standards, land-use rules, public health, food safety, financial regulations, Internet freedom, and more.

As a country we are all suffering from the ill effects of watching the Olympics (and other major sports events) on NBC. All of that "up close and personal" sports coverage that is devoid of any actual sports has found its way into our national psyche and into the minds of politicians.

The McMorris Rodgers counter-point said exactly zero. But everyone seemed to think that was normal.

How can one of the two major political parties get up in front of the nation and blather on about being the first person from her family to go to college, and personal choice, but not actually say anything of substance. She would make a great NBC sports commentator.

But congress? Where our representatives must understand very complex problems and write intelligent laws? I don't think she has the mental capacity.

Perhaps it's because we have lost all sense of reality after all those years of watching NBC only talk about the private lives of American athletes at the Olympics, and not about the sports performances of the best athlete.

Maybe we have become a completely substance-free society.

In 1863 Walter Kittredge penned a song that fits Israel and Palestine, two peoples that share a nomadic past, living in tents before there were pyramids, as certainly as it fit the Union and Confederacy:

"Many are the hearts that are weary tonight,
Wishing for the war to cease;
Many are the hearts looking for the right
To see the dawn of peace.
Tenting tonight, tenting tonight,
Tenting on the old camp ground.

"The lone wife kneels and prays with a sigh
That God his watch will keep
O'er the dear one away and the little dears nigh,
In the trundle bed fast asleep.

"Alas for those comrades of days gone by
Whose forms are missed tonight.
Alas for the young and true who lie
Where the battle flag braved the fight.

"We are tired of war on the old camp ground,
Many are dead and gone,
Of the brave and true who've left their homes,
Others been wounded long.

"We've been fighting today on the old camp ground,
Many are lying near;
Some are dead, and some are dying,
Many are in tears.

Most of the world is looking for the light in the Middle East, and to see the dawn of peace.

My feelings exactly. The Republican response was terrifyingly banal! But I have to say it's weirdness made it kind of interesting.

The President ever since the beginning of his first term tried hard to cooperate, and gave a lot of concessions to the Republicans. Then, when they saw that they thought wow! This was easy, let's meet here next month and do it again! So, they shut down the Government and skipped town without paying the bills they incurred.

Talk about ice breaking the President of the US last five years literally became the icebreaker, so much so recently we should have sent him to the Arctic Ocean to rescue the Russian scientists.

President Obama hit all the important points with ease, candor, elegance, and humor. His remark about the son of a bar keep rising to Speaker, the applause, and Speaker Boehner's graceful acknowledgement broke a lot of ice ... We're weary, fed up, and want to see elected leaders willing to josh, smile, and hammer out tough details. No one expects either side to give away the farm but at least take steps toward fair solutions.

My concern was how this was going to be delivered: the vocabulary, examples, enthusiasm, techniques used to hold Republicans accountable. It sets the tone for the 2014 election, which will be our last chance to nail down legislation needed to secure our recovery. our badly needed improvements in education, infrastructure, and inclusive economics.

My benchmark was the speeches made by FDR at moments of U.S. crisis. FDR always came across valuing our nation's values, valuing all the Americans who are the real engine of our economy, constantly urged collaboration between labor and owners, but was quick to warn he'd take action to circumvent political obstruction sacrificing working Americans.

By that benchmark, President Obama was superb. Vision, details, caring for the people, and nationally understood, memorable, humor-wrapped, pointed criticism. He declared he's putting the country on his back to win this one with us. Now we find out if Americans will fight and sacrifice to win an election for our prosperity or will be divided, again, by hate.

So "Obama declared independence from Congress," but "was not giving up on Congress altogether"? To me, this sounds a bit insulting to Democrat MCs. How much is increasing the minimum wage to federal contractors really going to promote change? Well, hope springs eternal, so the poet says.

Also, close Gitmo this year? We've been hearing that for 5 years.

Altogether, in my view, an uninspiring speech - "small ball," but realistic in recognizing the futility of attempting anything significant in the brief time till he becomes a de facto lame duck.

Peter Kelly
Palominas, Arizona

muezzin,

The protesters in Thailand are not "the rich," not in an American sense. They're more well educated probably than the pro-Thaksin faction, and more likely to live in urban settings. You are underestimating the extent to which corruption plays a role in SE Asian politics. And Thaksin and his family are tremendously corrupt.

As an example OF SEA corruption/politics, in the Philippines, Imelda Marcos has held elected national office for more than a decade. I would contend that her family's wealth has more to do with her current position rather than her innate capacity as a legislator.

The Thai conflict does not fit into the American narrative of the 1% against the masses, at least not in the way that you think it does.

The rich in Thailand, as everywhere else, resent devolution of power to the unwashed yet uppity masses. The Shinawatras have changed the discourse by bringing healthcare and education to the poor and this empowerment is what the Bangkok socialites - like Southern Republicans - cannot bear to endure.

I salute Ms. Malinee as someone who, by helping her country, is helping the entire planet with her decency, courage and common sense.
